topics.title: Brand meaning grows beyond the name
topics.summary: Arielle explains how brand meaning accrues over time (e.g., Disney=magic, Volvo=safety), arguing that a strong company can overcome a "bad" name while a great name mainly provides a boost.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Arielle’s background (Google/Gmail, Square, advising 100+ startups) and previews the episode’s three main areas: naming, brand strategy framework, and PR.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Two sponsor reads: Flatfile (CSV import/onboarding) and Unit (banking-as-a-service APIs for embedding financial products).

topics.title: Favorite project: launching Square Stand hardware
topics.summary: Arielle recounts leading the launch of Square Stand—positioning, seeding in key coffee shops, retail negotiations, packaging, and the challenge of moving Square upmarket with a paid hardware product.

topics.title: Square Stand positioning and target customer
topics.summary: They dig into how Square Stand was positioned for brick-and-mortar quick-serve businesses versus “ugly old” POS systems, emphasizing unified functionality and pride-of-place design on the counter.

topics.title: From jewelry maker to Square marketer
topics.summary: Arielle shares how using Square as a craft-fair merchant (and seeing sales lift) led her to email ex-Googlers at Square and ultimately interview and join—giving her deep empathy for early customers.

topics.title: First Round marketer-in-residence role explained
topics.summary: Arielle explains her path into consulting and how she supports First Round seed-stage companies on everything from naming and positioning to brand identity, launch planning, and hiring marketing.

topics.title: What makes a good startup name
topics.summary: Arielle outlines her preference for suggestive/evocative names (e.g., Seesaw, Maven) that click once you understand the product, and discusses the tradeoffs of “empty vessel” names like Yahoo or Eero.

topics.title: Naming process: brief, criteria, brainstorm
topics.summary: She presents a structured naming workflow: do positioning first, write a naming brief, evaluate against core criteria (trademark, domain, distinctiveness, timelessness, messaging fit, pronunciation, appearance, length), then brainstorm via positioning words and thematic “Jeopardy” categories to produce a shortlist.

topics.title: Product vs company naming and brand equity
topics.summary: They discuss when product names should be descriptive to leverage master-brand equity (e.g., Google Maps, Square Stand) versus when to diverge (e.g., Android, Cash).

topics.title: Bad names rarely kill great companies
topics.summary: Arielle expands on why strong strategy and marketing can imbue even mediocre names with meaning over time, reducing pressure to find a “perfect” name from a spreadsheet list.

topics.title: Common naming mistake and First Round value-add
topics.summary: Arielle warns against getting attached to early legal/incorporation “code names,” recommends intentionally ridiculous placeholders, and notes the high cost of professional naming firms—highlighting First Round’s included support.

topics.title: Brand strategy framework: purpose, positioning, personality
topics.summary: Arielle reframes brand as “who people think you are,” not just visuals, and introduces her startup-friendly framework: define purpose (why), positioning (role/value), and personality (how you show up), then express it via visual identity and voice.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Athletic Greens/AG1 sponsor read focused on daily nutrition, product iteration, and a bundle offer (vitamin D + travel packs).

topics.title: Brand work timing and defining purpose well
topics.summary: They discuss how quickly early-stage teams can complete brand strategy (often weeks) and why it saves time later; Arielle then defines “purpose” as a memorable, 10-year north star and gives examples (Google, Stripe, Nike) with guidance on phrasing it as a single sentence.
